He felt sure that it was to remove her from him, that the sudden de- termination of departure from home was made. He be- lieved that Mary had observed his growing interest and disapproved it, and wished by her abrupt departure to put an end to any expectations he might hitherto have indulged. He interpreted it as a delicate, but peremptory manner of expressing her disapprobation, and accepted it accordingly. The few words he had been betrayed into saying- expressive of his interest in Emily, were not so * strong as to receive the depth of the sentiment he cherished 'for her, and he had not even dared to believe that they were thus understood by her. He saw that during the time which elapsed between the announcement of their depart- ure, and its actual occurrence, there was an evident de- sire on Mary' spart, that all opportunity for a private inter- view with Emily should be avoided. Nothing remained for him but to acquiesce-to banish her image from his heart, until he could think of her -only as a friend and sister, which months of weary separation, danger and hardship had not enabled him to do. Nor had he in all his difficulties and- distresses, lost the hope for which alone he desired life, and by which he was able to endure, to struggle, and finally to overcome the barriers that se- parated him from the object of his earnest attachment. And now he had come to ask of those who knew her worth, permission to try and gain her affections. He did not care to have the past explained. Whether his con- jectures had been right or not, he did not even ask at present. He made no promises about what he might do or become, to be worthy of her. He felt that with such a stimulus to exertion, all the good within him must be
254 THE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, developed, and to live for her happiness was all he asked. How Mary replied to him, she did not tell m.. She gave him her sanction and her blessing however, to which in spirit I add mine. If he had confided all this to me some months ago, you perceive, he would never have played that desperate game. The headstrong folly of a man in love, whatever course it takes, is perfectly incom- prehensible to a looker-on. If he was in doubt how his suit would be received, why did he not satisfy himself by a plain home-question, and not go a thousand miles round to return at last to the same point from which he set out? O pride, pride! how out of place it seems in our dealings with each other! Truly love must delight in obstacles, if it will go out of its way to find them-and all the while he was periling life and limb, among wild beasts of the forest, and wild Indians of the prairie, his image was cherished in the true heart that loved him alone. About dinner-time I made my appearance below in a tasteful wrapper and my new cap with pink bows. I saw from the windows a group of our own people on the beach. Herbert and Mary walking to and fro, my hus- band and the young folks bobbing up and down among the rocks, and scrambling about in a most extraordinary and venturesome manner. It was a superb morning. A sort of shadow flitted across my soul as I thought it is the last-the last time my soul shall ever look upon this glorious landscape through mortal eyes. Afterwards, I was glad the last should be so bright and glorious, and the shadow passed by. It was only a cloud between me and Heaven. I went slowly down stairs. Just as my hand was on the latch of the door, I heard low tones in the room I was about to enter. Had I been younger and stronger, I might have retreated; as it was, I was forced to enter. Two happy faces shone upon me. I was made THE EVERY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 255 to feel that my presence was not unwelcome William drew my arm in his and led me to the sofa. "My dear children," said I, taking a hand of each, " what can have happened to make you both look so very satisfied I" I suppose it was a sort of awkward shyness, joined to my childish love of mischief, that made me ask the ques- tion, but it strangely belied my real feelings. But I can never grow old, and sometimes have a provoking double consciousness, which prompts me to manifest the very opposite of what I feel, possibly to prevent the exposure of emotion, which, if indulged, might go beyond bounds. But when I looked first at one and then at the other of my young friends, and felt the pressure of their thrilling hands in mine, I said to myself, "What signifies it at your age, and with one foot in the grave, to try and joke' with these happy souls!"Could anything I might say- could my sympathy with their happiness, paint the rain- bow of their hopes, with deeper tints, or add sweeter per- fume to the roses that bestrewed their path And yet, was I not nearer Paradise, nearer the Eternal Spring of life than they were? Did I not know from the Heavenly Oracle, that this prophecy of bliss now sounding in their ears, was an echo of the Divine Harmonies to which our being is attuned, and which Infinite love will sometime awaken in all their rich and endless combinations I, too, had known the rapture of such an hour, when the rose of youth bloomed on my cheek, and the pulse of health danced through every vein.. Through vicissitude and trial, and heartache-through joy and sorrow, the words of that prophecy still resounded in my soul-True love is immortal, unchangeable. Through whatever sorrows, and darkness, and adversity, it will not perish; it cannot be lost. Therefore be happy, young, ardent, trusting ones. Be happy without fear, only forget not
256 THE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, Him, from whose infinite love floweth this fullness of beatitude into your souls. These thoughts passed through my mind, crowding upon me so fast that I did not speak for some time. Wil- liam was the first to break the silence. "Why could you not have Spared me the ordeal I im- posed upon myself?" he asked' "One word, from you, would have been enough, and yet you withheld it." "Ungrateful boy!"I replied. "Did I not, in every way that real friendship -to say nothing of womanly curiosity-could dictate, try to gain your confidence, and you would not be persuaded to trust me? Did I not point out the folly of your joining that silly expedition, and advise you to go eastward instead and did you not refuse to be advised-headstrong, that you were-perverse, self- willed, proud, and everything else that is provoking?" "But one little word of encouragement would have changed my course at once," he continued. "And by what right do you suppose I could have spoken it?"I asked, assuming a righteous indignation. "By whose authority? What reason had I, or any one else, to suppose this little girl cared for you Surely she never spoke to me of her preferences. It was not my part to seek to penetrate her maidenly reserve. In a mat- ter that concerned your happiness so nearly, it would seem natural that you should interrogate. And how did I know you loved the child?" "You must have known it," he replied. "Mrs. Herbert must have known it, and she -Emily--ah - yes -she knew it. She never doubted. God bless her! But how much I have lost! This is the bitter drop in my cup of happiness now; the thought that all might have been mine months ago! So much bliss is lost from my life, and nobody held me back!" THE EVERY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 257 "Held you back, William!"I exclaimed. "You strong, brawny, willful man Who would think of hold- ing you back, when you were determined to go?" What malicious spirit stirred the depths within me, as he said these words, "For me there is no past A"And yet, within that dark domain she dwells to whose ear that voice was divinest music-to whom those words of love once were life-Mabel, Mabel! The light of that world where she dwells, who was thy heart's first love, William, is never dimmed by selfish longing. We cannot penetrate these mysteries of our being. I knew my presence was not unwelcome, and yet I felt I had staid long enough. Those words, never said too often, must be repeated over and over again-as they could not be repeated if I were by. Besides, I found myself growing serious and thoughtful, and I wanted to be alone. 22
258 THE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, "There is," said I, rising to go and looking at Wil- liam-" there is something firmer than the everlasting hills, and I am glad you have no further need of proof." ' He answered by a grasp of my hand. Emily blushed crimson, and hid her face on my shoulder. I pressed her dear, shrinking form to my heart. It beats yet-thanks to the kind Father!-with human sympathies. If there is an hour in mortal life, whose intensity of happiness will live as long as the soul's consciousness, it is that, when the heart that loves first feels it is be- loved. The memory of that hour in my own life, was the key which admitted me into the sacred temple of their happiness. I could only say, "God bless you both!"- and remembering that I had left my knitting up-stairs, I made a timely exit. William insisted upon giving me the support of his arm in ascending the stairs. "If anything could make me happier, than to be assured of her love, it would be your sympathy, to whom she is so dear," said he. "You have it, my friend," said I. "My heartfelt sym- pathy-my blessing on you both!" To-morrow I must leave our happy friends for a while. How glad I am that I leave them so very happy! But two days ago, it was an effort to wear even an outside cheerfulness, the habit of anxiety was so strong upon us. Why will we not learn trust even in the darkest hours It might have been otherwise. I thought it would be coming home to die. Mary and her party remained at Boston, but will pass a week or more with me before their departure for the West.- Possibly we may all return together. I miss them hourly. I should like to be an eye-witness of the bliss of my two young friends. Emily's delicate health is now William's greatest anxiety. His tenderness is beautiful. The little Willie is, of course, the pet of the family. He is a glorious little fellow. I can see something of his mother's expression in his face, although his features are more like the father's. Gentle Mabel, loving, and tenderly beloved. Is she forgotten? How like a dream must his early love seem to William now. These autumn leaves are falling over the grave of his wife, far away. I was about to say, how sad! but I was wrong. The heart of youth must have a living, present object for its love. Sad and lonely his life would be without a home. A few days ao an old fend of y mot A few days ago an old friend of my mother's called
260 ThE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, upon me. She had met my children returning from school with her own grandchildren, and learning whose they were, was impelled to call on me, as she said, for my mother's sake. They had been young together. They were married about the same time-they had been mem- bers of the same church, and she was one of the friends who stood beside my mother's dying pillow. I was glad to see her; yet her visit left a painful impression for a time, that I could not shake off. She belongs to the rigid sect of Puritans, whose ancestors were among the first settlers of this New England town. There was a pre- cision, a formality in her manner which chilled the free expression of my feelings. She had heard that I was a consumptive and not long for this world, but evidently thought, by my manner and appearance, that I was igno- rant of my real situation, and the near approach of death. It certainly could not have been owing to any frivolity or lightness of manner; it must have been from the cheer- fulness with which I spoke of things appertaining to life. She did not mean to be obtrusive, but could not rest easy until she had obtained, by a series of close questions, my confession of faith. Now, you know, religious discussions have, from time immemorial, been distasteful to me. Not that I am unable or unwilling to give a reason for the faith that is in me. Not that I have no reason to give, as some may suppose, from my dislike of argumentation; nor is it that I am only a negative receiver of the doc- trines by which I hope to have arrived at truth. No one can love them better, rfo one can attach higher importance to them. They are, indeed, my life. On them are based my hopes of happiness here and hereafter. By them I have sought to know how to live, and in them I am wil- ling to die. It is because they lie so near my heart that I am unwilling to drag them forth for discussion, and THE EVERY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 261 seek to explain them merely to satisfy the curiosity of another. I had lapsed, in her opinion, from the faith of my fathers, and was spiritually a cast-away. She wept over me-abjuring me for the sake of my mother-for the sake of the blessed Saviour who died for me, to lay hold on the faith by which alone I might hope to obtain salva- tion. She asked me if I had any objection to her offering up a prayer. Of course, I had none, and she bowed her aged limbs in my presence, and prayed the Almighty, before it was too late, to save my soul and sanctify me through the truth. There was a touching earnestness in her appeal and in her manner, which moved me to tears; but my faith is too firmly fixed to be shaken now. When she arose I thanked her, but I could say nothing more. I should have loved to talk with her about my mother's early life, her last ihours, and many things relating to her. It would have been sweet to refresh my memory with her image, and have the dim outline filled out by one who knew her so intimately. I had often been told of her spotless life and peaceful death, but I had never asked her creed. I felt that her hope and trust was mine: that she had gone before me to our common Father, and it has long been one of my sweetest anticipations that, when my spirit first enters upon its untried life, she will be near to welcome me: I shall not be alone. It is a hard faith that would destroy our trust in a good Father, and place on the throne of the universe an arbitrary-an inexorable judge. I had not the strength, even if I had felt the wish, to talk much with my aged friend. I thanked her as cheer- fully as I could, for her kind concern in my spiritual wel- fare, and told her that, what had been truth to me in life, I felt would not fail me in the hour of death, and that with a heart willing to be taught of God, and trusting in
262 THE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, his infinite love and wisdom, I did-not fear to rest my hopes of salvation with him. He who had guided me thus far in life, had given his promise never to forsake those who put their trust in him. Her visit was kindly meant, but I hope she will not come again. * * * * We are all together once more. The days are soft and balmy, and the forests are gorgeous in their autumn drapery. My husband gives me a drive every afternoon. I enjoy more than I can express. We talk of the fitwre as if there were an earthly future for me as well as for him- self I say nothing to remind him that it cannot be, for I know he does it consciously. He does not, cannot dwell upon the thought that I must leave him. Nor need he. It would not help him to bear my loss, and it would take away from the joy of the present. So we speak of what is to happen, of the children, and of our hopes and fears for them, as if we were to watch their unfolding life to- gether. So I believe we shall. Mary is busy preparing her little folks for winter. Emily and William have the world to themselves: the world of reality and the world of dreams. The rose has come back to the fair cheek of our darling, and her strength improves daily. Yet we still fear she will never be vigorous and strong. The beautiful proportions of her figure are lost, but she does not seem deformed to us. She is transformed by the pure soul which shines through her whole being. They will be married as soon as Mary is settled at her own home. * * * * Do you think it possible that I can be getting well? after having made up my mind that I must soon die, that I may dare to entertain a hope of recovery? I know how consumptives deceive themselves often and oten. I THE EVEREYDAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 263 remember how it was with poor T - . He always talked of getting well; always said he thought he was a little better. None of his friends undeceived him, and he was never brighter or more cheerful than the few days that preceded his death. I thought, when I saw him last, what a beautiful and kindly provision it is of our heavenly Father, thus to soothe with hope, the long and wearisome months of a lingering disease. You recollect how it troubled the conscientious clergyman who visited him during his illness, that he did not seem to be aware of his actual condition. But his sister, who knew him better than any one else, insisted that he should not be dis- turbed. I remember what she said. "Why should we trouble him? I know that he does not dread death, nor fear to meet it, although he loves life and enjoys it. It anybody ought to enjoy life it is he; and, indeed, for such as he, there is no death." He was not a man to talk much of his feelings, his hopes, or his fears-not even to those he loved best; but he needed not to speak in words: his life was its own interpreter. The evening before he died, he was bright and cheerful, and more tender than usual, particularly to the children, his little brothers and sisters. After an hour of delightful communion he retired to rest as usual. Early in the morning, as was her custom, his sister, his sole nurse, went in with his cup of tea which he took in bed. No hand was out- stretched to clasp hers-no voice spoke the morning wel- come. The hush of death was in the room. His spirit had passed away, all bright and warm and glowing with its purified human affections, into the bosom of the Infin- ite love. At first, as she afterwards told me, it gave her a shock to find him dead. The thought that he had died alone was painful. This, however, was but a momentary pang. As she stood gazing upon his noble features, so

Since you cannot be with us all the time, I will keep you informed of our doings and sayings. To return then to our domestic details, I will relate a little conversation we had, the other evening, about our friend Mr. Rochester. He is not yet married, although I predicted he would not endure a long engagement, which proves I am not always, in such affairs, a true prophet. Rosalie says he is a daily visitor at their house, and always punctual to tea. She learned the other day from an old resident, who knew him years ago when he Was a gay young man in society, some particulars of his life. Handsome, she declares, as Adonis, but so wild, so extra- THE EVERY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 265 vagant-his father could do nothing with him. Of course, there is but one satisfactory solution of the problem how the change was brought about, which.,transformed him into the Mr. Rochester of our acquaintance. What makes the crusty old bachelors and unhappy old maids in the world? Crosses in love, is the reply, stereotyped ages ago. This it was, in truth, which changed the current of our reckless young hero's life, and made him what he is, or rather what he was a year ago. He didn't take the disease kindly, and it left him terribly scarred; but the scars, after all, are only skin deep. Now that he is filled with happiness in the widow's genial society, he looks a score of years younger. Happiness is the best cosmetic. Well, to go back in my story, Frederick Rochester, young, handsome, gay, and rich, fell in love with a poor, simple, uneducated little cousin of his-beautiful as an houri, but fickle as the wind. I think her name was Bertha; I shall call her so at all hazards, for Bertha sounds rather capricious. She was a distant relative, whom he had never seen, until she came with her mother to his father's house. Old Mr. Rochester, learning the misfortunes of his kinswoman, offered her a home, little thinking of the syren who was to charm away his son's reason and judgment, and finally destroy his happiness. They came. The mother, to assume the care of the house, which had been left to take care of itself since the death of Mrs. Rochester, and the daughter, to bewitch her gay, young, spendthrift cousin., How he fell in love, desperately, madly, as Rosalie says, with the beautiful Bertha-how his father stormed about it awhile, and then gave up, because he saw 'twas no use trying to dam up the swollen torrent of his impetuous affections-how she seemed to return his passion-all this you will find recorded in the chronicles of true lovers 23

How he promised to sow his wild oate and be a steady man, and swore that what he had needed heretofore, was such an angel to guide him; and how his friends were compelled to acknowledge that, after al it was the making of him, this bondage of heart and soul to the wily little god-all this you can compare with the records of your own observation, and you will appre. eliate our hero's position. But Bertha was too pretty to be unobserved - too fond of admiration to be willing to bloom in the quiet nook of a secluded country home. She went to church, to singing-school, to village parties and festivals, and a great many young men, besides Frederick Rochester, contrived to tell her by word of mouth, or sign of some kind, how pretty they thought her; and her own glass told her the same story many times a day. Still Frederick seemed to be the chosen one. Her mother impressed upon her the fact of her cousin's nice property-rich father-great expectations; and these were weighty considerations: for the truth must be told, she had no heart-she was nothing but a weak, vain, frivolous, coquettish little beauty. Affairs went on, however, smoothly and pleasantly between them, till sud- denly, by one of those mysterious turns of the wheel, which nobody expects, there came reverses to the family of old Mr. Rochester. Some business house, in which the greater part of his property was invested, failed and his large fortune was lost. He bore it like a man, for he was a man. He had made his money, and had known what it was to work hard. A small competence remained, barely sufficient to enable the family to live respectably; and Frederick was compelled to do as his father had done before hiin-seek his fortune. He went into business, through his father's influence, in one of our large cities. He had an object whereby all toil was sweetened. Bertha THE EVEBY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE.. 26 was the pole-star of his ambition. For her he labored to be rich--labored hard, indefatigably, unremittingly, and successfully; but just as the summit of his hopes was gained, and buoyant with expectation, he was preparing the home for his fair bride elect, he received a letter from his father, that his angel had eloped with a young South- erner, and was on her way to his plantation in Georgia. Imagine the downfall of his hopes.! Imagine the shock to his pride and his affections! Nothing could be done, however. She had left him voluntarily-was the wife of another. The future was a blank to him. Nobody could offer him sympathy, for his nature was too proud to desire it. He threw up all business, and off he went on a voyage round the world. The only relief to his despair seemed to be in constant change. Storm and tempest, danger and hardship were congenial to his perturbed spirit. He was gone a long time. What he suffered, no one ever knew, but he lived through it, and came out of the con- flict stern, ascetic, joyless, as we knew him--the very antipodes of hiq early manhood. Firm as a rock, he set himself against the evils of society, the pomp and cir- cumstance which attend wealth, the abuse of power, the corruptions of party. But the one great curse of slavery was the chief point of attack. The very names of South- erner and slaveholder stirred the depths of his indigna- tion. He refused all terms of brotherhood with them. Doubtless, he thought a true feeling of philanthropy lay at the bottom of this deep aversion. Far be it from me to probe the old heart-wounds now. He had no reason to look with charity on southern institutions and influ- ence. But I honor his principles, and will not question his motives too narrowly. Few of us could stand a close scrutiny of motives. I hope, through his labors and sacrifices, the blot upon our country's escutcheon is,
268 THE OLD CORNER CUPBOARD; OR, dimmed, and I know many a poor fugitive may thank Mr. Rochester that he is a free man. I hope he will not relax his efforts now, or forget, as he sits in his easy-chair gazing, as I have no doubt he does, on the widow's fresh- complexioned, kindly-hearted face, that " the trail of the serpent" still lingers in Eden. Rosalie says he is really lovable, that all the young folks are won by his cheeriness. I always felt sure he had a heart, and I am glad it is thawed out. The philan- thropy of the head is like the sun in winter-light without heat-but the philanthropy of the heart will gradually melt away all evil and prejudice. But good-by, Mr. Rochester. If you had your life to live over again, with your present experience, I am sure you would not let the fickleness and caprice of a weak girl make your best years miserable. How differently trials affect us! Speaking of trials, reminds me of a letter I received, yesterday, from Lizzie-a sad letter. She feels alone with all of us gone. She shrinks from making new friends, but dreads more the thought of returning to her old ones. How long it may be before the dove of peace broods over the troubled waters of her soul! How sad is the picture of her past life! What though I tell her to look not upon it, repeating to her again and again, what I have so often been compelled to say to myself: "Let the dead bury its dead!"It still sounds in her ears like a- mockery. How can she forget, when the very effort to do so, forces her to remember? After all, how little we can help one another to bear sorrow! We hold up to our stricken friends the feeble lamp of our experience, pointing out this and that path which seemed, as we trod it, to bring us nearer to the source of peace. We point onward, where the Eter- nal sits enthroned, and say: Strive ,pward, be strong, be hopeful, be steadfast! and even while we are speaking, THE EVERY-DAY LIFE OF EVERY-DAY PEOPLE. 269 our own feeble footsteps totter-the distance between us and the heights to which we aspire, grows immeasurably far off; as we gaze upon it, shadowy apprehensions of unknown dangers in wait for us, fall dark over the way, and we can only say, Let us kneel together-pilgrims as we are--let us trust to the arm that never faileth, to the love that never sleeps. Where is all our boasted self- reliance when the heart is overwhelmed? Humility is forced upon us in the hour of sorrow. It is not in rest- less striving, any more than by patient waiting, that we attain to heavenly states. Besides, she says, it would be a shame to make her aunt the trouble of moving, when she is so nicely fixed, and Mr. Rochester has got so into the habit of com- ing there to pass his evenings. She thinks if she were to be established in another home, there would be an addi- tional motive, in the loneliness of the widow, to hasten on a certain event to which matters have long been tending. We all agree with her, that nothing is wanting to com- plete the reform of our reformer, than that he should be a married man.
